item.title: Word of the Day: abrogate
item.description: This word has appeared in four articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
item.dc:creator: The Learning Network

item.title: Stephen Colbert Doubts Trump Can Run Two Countries at Once
item.description: “The Late Show” host said the president couldn’t possibly run two nations, because “he can’t even run.”
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)
Late Night with Seth Meyers (TV Program)
The Daily Show with Jon Stewart (TV Program)

item.title: Health Dept. to Freeze $10 Billion in Funding to 5 Democratic States
item.description: The funding pause could jeopardize child care and other programs that serve hundreds of thousands of households in California, Colorado, Illinois, Minnesota and New York.
item.dc:creator: Minho Kim

media:content.media:credit: Michael A. McCoy for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A Department of Health and Human Services spokesman cited “massive amounts of fraud” as the reason for the freeze, but did not provide evidence of fraud in four of the states.

item.title: Jamie Raskin: Jan. 6 Never Ended
item.description: Five years after Jan. 6, 2021, we are still caught up in a struggle over the meaning of that day.
item.dc:creator: Jamie Raskin
item.category: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack

media:content.media:credit: Nate Gowdy

item.title: Maduro’s Gesture Was Not Just a Peace Sign
item.description: The captured authoritarian leader flashed a symbol that many took to be a defiant peace sign. Loyal lawmakers repeated the gesture at a session in Caracas.
item.dc:creator: Annie Correal

media:content.media:credit: Adam Gray/Bloomberg
media:content.media:description: Venezuela’s leader, Nicolás Maduro, arriving in New York, on Saturday.

item.title: Venezuela’s Machado Praises Trump in Fox News Interview
item.description: María Corina Machado, the Venezuelan opposition leader, offered to share her Nobel Peace Prize with President Trump. He has refused to back her.
item.dc:creator: Francesca Regalado

media:content.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: María Corina Machado at a rally during the country’s presidential election in 2024.

item.title: Venezuela se prepara para una caída catastrófica de la producción de crudo tras la incautación de petroleros
item.description: Venezuela podría perder la mayor parte de sus ingresos por exportaciones este año, según estimaciones internas del gobierno, un golpe que desencadenaría una crisis humanitaria.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev

media:content.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez para The New York Times
media:content.media:description: El presidente Trump quiere que las empresas petroleras estadounidenses vuelvan a Venezuela, la cual cuenta con las mayores reservas de petróleo del mundo.

item.title: Venezuela Braces for Economic Collapse From U.S. Blockade
item.description: Venezuela could lose the bulk of its export revenues this year if the U.S. blockade stays in place, according to internal government estimates, a scenario that would set off a humanitarian crisis.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev

media:content.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Employees outside Venezuela’s state oil company, known as PDVSA, in Caracas in October.

item.title: Quote of the Day: Giving Shelter Dogs a Day in the Sun, and a Second Chance
item.description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, January 6, 2026.

item.title: Zelensky’s Assessment Darkens as Europeans Gather to Talk Peace
item.description: With Russia still seen as unlikely to stop fighting, the Ukrainian leader’s tone has shifted from upbeat to cautionary.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer

media:content.media:credit: Tetiana Dzhafarova/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine during a meeting of national security advisers of European countries in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Saturday.

item.title: In China, a Debate About Political Power Ignites After Maduro’s Capture
item.description: The reactions online revealed a Chinese society divided: Some saw what happened in Venezuela as a playbook for seizing Taiwan, while others warned about ideological rigidity.
item.dc:creator: Li Yuan

media:content.media:credit: The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Supporters of Nicolás Maduro gathering near the Presidential Palace to demand his release.

item.title: Corrections: Jan. 6, 2026
item.description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Jan. 6, 2026.

item.title: At Refugee Camps, Most Birthdays Fall on New Year’s
item.description: When an exodus of Rohingya fled to Bangladesh a decade ago, the United Nations recorded many of their birthdays as Jan. 1. The date serves as a reminder of a lost identity.
item.dc:creator: Verena Hölzl
item.category: United Nations High Commission for Refugees

media:content.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Rohingya refugees arriving in Bangladesh in 2017.

item.title: Stephen Miller Asserts U.S. Has Right to Take Greenland
item.description: In a CNN interview, the top Trump aide also echoed the president’s intent to run Venezuela as he laid out a case for the United States’ controlling weaker states by flexing its military might.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron

media:content.media:credit: Anna Rose Layden for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Stephen Miller, the White House deputy chief of staff, at the White House last year. Mr. Miller’s remarks were part of a broader rhetorical push in interviews to justify American imperialism and a vision for a new world order.

item.title: NYT Crossword Answers for Jan. 6, 2026
item.description: One way or another, you’ll solve Paul Coulter’s crossword.
item.dc:creator: Sam Corbin

media:content.media:credit: Jessica Ebelhar/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The twist in this crossword puzzle is kind of perfect.

item.title: 2026 Travel Destinations: 52 Places to Go This Year
item.description: Our list for the new year features an eclipse, a revolution and a tiger reserve. What’s on yours?

media:content.media:credit: Hiroko Masuike/The New York Times

item.title: An Homage to Our Last Sunsets
item.description: A trip to Antarctica at this time of year means a month of no darkness. Our climate reporter Raymond Zhong reflects on one of the last sunsets that he and our photographer Chang W. Lee will experience for some time.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong, Chang W. Lee, Christina Thornell, Leila Medina and Jon Miller

item.title: Map: 5.7-Magnitude Earthquake Shakes Japan
item.description: View the location of the quake’s epicenter and shake area.
item.dc:creator: William B. Davis, Madison Dong, Judson Jones, John Keefe, Joey K. Lee and Bea Malsky

media:content.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Trump’s Post About Slain Minnesota Lawmaker Dismays Her Children
item.description: The son and daughter of Melissa and Mark Hortman have asked the president to remove a social media post promoting a conspiracy theory about the assassination.
item.dc:creator: Christina Morales

media:content.media:credit: Tim Gruber for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Sophie and Colin Hortman stood behind the caskets of their parents, Mark and Melissa Hortman, after a funeral service in Minneapolis in June.

item.title: Outside at Maduro’s Court Appearance: Flags, Chants and Venezuelans’ Quiet Pain
item.description: A demonstration outside the building where Nicolás Maduro was arraigned was a ritual of New York public protest, but one that sprang from personal wounds inflicted a continent away.
item.dc:creator: Olivia Bensimon and Maia Coleman

media:content.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Protesters on Monday facing off across barricades in a park outside a federal courthouse in Lower Manhattan on Monday.

item.title: Steve Sheetz, Who Popularized Convenience Stores as a C.E.O., Dies at 77
item.description: Sheetz, a family-owned company that started with a single convenience store in Altoona, Pa., has more than 800 locations in seven states.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor

media:content.media:credit: Nic Antaya for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The chain has more than 800 convenience stores in seven states.

item.title: Cuban Deaths in U.S. Venezuela Strikes Confirm Ties Between Countries
item.description: The Maduro regime was long propped up by Cuba’s armed forces and intelligence agencies. Many Cubans were reported killed in the American military action.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles

media:content.media:credit: The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela and his wife, Cilia Flores, during a pro-government march last month in Caracas. Many of the bodyguards that protected Mr. Maduro were Cuban.

item.title: Venezuela’s Legislators Offer Scorn as Trump Demands Obedience
item.description: The convening of the National Assembly made it clear that Maduro loyalists remain entrenched across Venezuelan institutions after decades of purges and crackdowns on dissent.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero, María Victoria Fermín and Annie Correal
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

media:content.media:credit: The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A pro-Maduro demonstration near Parliament in Caracas on Monday.

item.title: Brain Health Challenge: Try the MIND Diet
item.description: Today, we’ll show you how to eat more of them.
item.dc:creator: Dana G. Smith

item.title: A.I. Images of Maduro Spread Rapidly, Despite Safeguards
item.description: Deepfakes of Venezuela’s ousted president, Nicolás Maduro, flooded the internet after his capture, in a new collision of breaking news and artificial intelligence.
item.dc:creator: Stuart A. Thompson and Tiffany Hsu

item.title: Trump’s Foray Into Venezuela Could Embolden Russia’s and China’s Own Aggression
item.description: While both countries were allied with Nicolás Maduro, the U.S. attack could give them justification to use force in other spheres, analysts said.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski

media:content.media:credit: Pool photo by Evgenia Novozhenina
media:content.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia at the Kremlin last May. China and Russia both have close ties to Nicolás Maduro.

item.title: Why Trump Refused to Back Venezuela’s Machado: Fears of Chaos, and Fraying Ties
item.description: U.S. intelligence suggested María Corina Machado, Venezuela’s opposition leader, would struggle to lead the government. But her relationship with Trump officials had been souring for months.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Julian E. Barnes

media:content.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The opposition leader María Corina Machado and her surrogate presidential candidate, Edmundo González, at a rally in Caracas, the Venezuelan capital, in 2024.

item.title: Venezuela Detained and Deported Members of the Foreign Press
item.description: Military officers detained 14 members of the news media during a National Assembly session. All were released after their phones were searched. One was deported.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega

media:content.media:credit: The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Demonstrators walking toward the National Assembly during a march in Venezuela’s capital, Caracas, as the new National Assembly began on Monday.

item.title: Appeals Court Upholds Prohibition on Trump’s Medical Research Cuts
item.description: The ruling on Monday upheld a lower court’s judgment in April that the Trump administration could not drastically slash funding from the National Institutes of Health.
item.dc:creator: Zach Montague

media:content.media:credit: Hailey Sadler for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A federal court of appeals ruled that the Trump administration could not cut federal funding given out by the National Institutes of Health.

item.title: Donald Trump Was Right to Oust Maduro
item.description: President Trump made a bold decision, and it was a stunning success.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Kroenig
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:credit: Maxwell_Briceno/Reuters

item.title: Mamdani Chooses a Bernie Sanders Aide as His Communications Director
item.description: Anna Bahr, who leads communications for the Vermont senator and worked on his presidential campaign, is the latest appointee to a high-profile role in the Mamdani administration.
item.dc:creator: Sally Goldenberg and Benjamin Oreskes

media:content.media:credit: Michael M. Santiago/Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Anna Bahr, center, the communications director for Senator Bernie Sanders, left, will leave his office to join the administration of Mayor Zohran Mamdani, right.

item.title: Zohran Mamdani Targets Junk Fees and Hidden Charges in Executive Orders
item.description: Trying to protect consumers by going after deceptive business practices has been an early focus of the new mayor’s administration.
item.dc:creator: Jeffery C. Mays
item.category: Department of Consumer and Worker Protection (NYC)

media:content.media:credit: Mimi d’Autremont for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Mayor Zohran Mamdani spoke at an outdoor gym in Hunter’s Point South Park in Queens.

item.title: Mamdani and Hochul Celebrate Congestion Pricing a Year After Contentious Debut
item.description: The tolling program, which charges motorists to enter Manhattan’s busiest streets, had a largely successful first year after a delayed start.
item.dc:creator: Stefanos Chen and Winnie Hu

media:content.media:credit: Mimi d’Autremont for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Mayor Zohran Mamdani, center, and Gov. Kathy Hochul, to his left, agree on the need for congestion pricing, but seem to still be apart on the mayor’s goal of making buses free.

item.title: Maduro’s Arraignment Begins as U.N. and Protesters Speak Out
item.description: As Nicolás Maduro, the ousted leader of Venezuela and his wife faced charges in a federal court in Lower Manhattan on Monday, protesters and global leaders responded with mixed thoughts.
item.dc:creator: Michael Anthony Adams, Kassie Bracken, Jamie Leventhal, Jeremy Raff and Daniel Fetherston

media:content.media:credit: The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Protesters waving Venezuelan flags in front of the federal courthouse.

item.title: A Revival of Venezuela’s Oil Industry Poses a Challenge for Canada
item.description: The two countries both produce heavy oil, which is difficult to refine, and have relied historically on American refineries to buy it.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen

media:content.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A refinery in Punto Fijo, Venezuela, in 2021. Historically Canada and Venezuela were direct competitors in the oil business.

item.title: What to Know About the New Childhood Vaccine Schedule
item.description: The U.S. federal government slashed the number of diseases that all children are advised to be vaccinated against to 11 from 17.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor, Dani Blum and Teddy Rosenbluth

media:content.media:credit: Laila Stevens for The New York Times

item.title: David R. Young, 89, Is Dead; Nixon Aide Helped Steer the ‘Plumbers’
item.description: He took part in White House machinations to stop leaks of classified information by overseeing an investigative unit that resorted to burglary. He then cooperated with Watergate investigators.
item.dc:creator: Robert D. McFadden

item.title: ¿Colombia, México o Groenlandia? Trump ofrece pistas sobre su siguiente acto
item.description: Envalentonado por la rápida captura del venezolano Nicolás Maduro, el presidente estadounidense deja ver hacía donde podría apuntar a continuación.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times

item.title: Hilton ‘Maliciously Canceled’ Immigration Agents’ Reservations, DHS Says
item.description: As the U.S. ramps up deportation efforts in Minnesota, the Department of Homeland Security claimed on social media that a Hampton Inn had canceled agents’ bookings.
item.dc:creator: Christine Chung

media:content.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Scores of Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents have been deployed in Minneapolis in recent weeks.

item.title: Nvidia Details New A.I. Chips and Autonomous Car Project With Mercedes
item.description: At the CES conference, Jensen Huang, the company’s chief executive, said the more efficient and powerful chip would begin shipping later this year.
item.dc:creator: Tripp Mickle

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Nvidia’s Vera Rubin on display at a company conference in October. The new chip is named for an astronomer whose research supported the existence of dark matter.

item.title: Six Big Political Questions for 2026
item.description: A wildly important midterm year is off to a chaotic start, with a raid in Venezuela, an uneasy economy and more. Here’s what we’re curious about.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A Trump rally in North Carolina last month.

item.description: Also, health officials scaled back the number of vaccines recommended for children. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.

item.title: Maduro Laywer Is Barry Pollack, Who Also Defended Assange
item.description: Mr. Pollack has also represented Julian Assange and an official of Enron.
item.dc:creator: Santul Nerkar

media:content.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Barry Pollack, second from right, has long experience negotiating with the federal government.

item.title: Justice Dept. Drops Claim That Venezuela’s ‘Cartel de los Soles’ Is an Actual Group
item.description: Last year, before capturing President Nicolás Maduro, the Trump administration designated a Venezuelan slang term for drug corruption in the military as a terrorist organization and said he led it.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage

media:content.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Nicolás Maduro in 2024. In a revised indictment, the Justice Department abandoned its claims that “Cartel de los Soles” was an actual organization.

item.title: Vote on the 17 Ways Mamdani Could Improve NYC
item.description: More housing and public toilets. Fewer trucks. We canvassed dozens of experts on ideas for making the built city more livable. What do you think?
item.dc:creator: Michael Kimmelman

media:content.media:credit: Daniel Arnold

item.title: Critics Choice Awards 2026: Unforgettable Looks From Ariana Grande, Megan Stalter and More
item.description: Saturated colors, sculptural silhouettes, doses of whiplash and more.
item.dc:creator: The Styles Desk

media:content.media:credit: Caroline Brehman/Reuters
media:content.media:description: The actress Erin Doherty wore a strapless gown in an uplifting shade of spearmint.

item.title: Maduro Says He Is a Prisoner of War, Not a Defendant. The Words Matter.
item.description: His simple statement in federal court was aimed directly at contradictions in the Trump administration’s actions in the Caribbean.
item.dc:creator: Hurubie Meko

media:content.media:credit: Jefferson Siegel for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The Federal District Court building in Lower Manhattan on Monday.

item.title: Russia Once Offered U.S. Control of Venezuela for Free Rein in Ukraine
item.description: The exchange offer was recounted at the time in congressional testimony by Fiona Hill, who ran Russian and European affairs on the National Security Council during the first Trump administration.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar

media:content.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: In 2019, Fiona Hill told a Congressional hearing that the Russians “were signaling very strongly that they wanted to somehow make some very strange swap arrangement between Venezuela and Ukraine.”

item.title: Entering the Antarctic Sea Ice, and a New World
item.description: After 10 days with only the open ocean and the occasional iceberg at our sides, sailing into the sea ice felt like crossing into a whole new realm.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong

media:content.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: At U.N. Emergency Meeting, U.S. Allies Criticize Military Action in Venezuela
item.description: American allies including France objected to the military incursion into a sovereign state and the capture of the Venezuelan president as a violation of international law.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

media:content.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
